title-group.article-title: Thermal stability and electrical behavior of polydimethylsiloxane nanocomposites with carbon nanotubes and carbon black fillers

contrib-group.aff: 1School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Engineering Campus, Malaysia

author-notes.corresp: A Azizan, School of Materials and Mineral Resources Engineering, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Engineering Campus, 14300 Nibong Tebal, Penang, Malaysia Email: azizan@eng.usm.my

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this work, the performance of polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) nanocomposites with carbon black (CB) and multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWCNT) fillers was studied. The carbon nanofillers were first introduced in the solvent to promote an adequate dispersion. The silicone rubber was then reinforced with the carbon nanofillers by a mechanical mixing process followed by film casting. It was found that only small amount of MWCNTs is required to reach the percolation threshold that produces high electrical conductivity. Filler size and segregation, as observed by scanning electron microscopy, play important roles in determining the electrical properties of silicone elastomer filled composites. Transmission electron microscopy was also performed to examine the tube–tube interaction of MWCNT in silicone rubber. The MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposites have higher electrical conductivity value compared to the CB/PDMS nanocomposite. The percolation threshold for MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposites was approximately 1.0 vol% of MWCNT loading with a value of –4.06 log σ (S/cm). On the contrary, no obvious percolation threshold of CB/PDMS nanocomposites was observed, as the CB fillers added from 0.5 to 2.0 vol% in the PDMS. The MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposite also showed better thermal stability than the CB/PDMS nanocomposite. The onset temperature for 0.5 vol% of MWCNT/PDMS and CB/PDMS nanocomposites were 528°C and 492°C, respectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently, nanocomposites incorporating nanoscale fillers in a polymer matrix have been studied.1–3 Low levels of nanoscale fillers, as compared to micro-size fillers, produce desirable composite properties due to their high surface-to-volume ratios that dramatically change the properties and the performance of the nanocomposites. The extensive use of nanofillers may produce lightweight composites with enhanced yield strength and electrical and thermal conductivity, especially in electronic packaging applications.1–5 Various types of reinforcing fillers, such as metals, ceramics and carbon, have been widely used in polymer matrices to obtain composites with high electrical and thermal properties.6–11 As known, different filler dimensions have diverse effects on the composite properties.

Few reports have been published on the electrical properties of silicone rubbers combined with carbon nanofillers.12–15 Various factors affect the conductive mechanism, including the amount of conductive fillers, the size and shape of the fillers, the filler–filler interactions, the filler–matrix interactions and the tendency of the filler to aggregates.12,16 Conductive fillers at low concentrations are separated from each other and the electrical properties of the composite are poor due to the domination of the polymer matrix over the fillers in the composite. By increasing the filler concentration, a phenomenon called the percolation threshold is observed at certain loading when the first continuous chains of linked conductive filler particles are present. Increasing the conductive filler concentration above this point does not significantly increase the electrical conductivity of the composite. Above the percolation threshold, the distance between fillers becomes shorter. Thus, limiting the carrier transport of the electrical conductivity creates the capacitive contacts between fillers.17 Song and Youn16 dispersed the carbon nanotube (CNT) in epoxy matrix and found that the composite attains a percolation threshold of less than 0.5 wt%. The conductivity value reached approximately 10–3–10–2 after adding the CNT up to 1.5 wt%. Therefore, even after adding more fillers in the matrix above the percolation threshold, there is no significant difference in conductivity value. The conductive mechanism between the carbon nanofillers and the polymer matrix creates a three-dimensional conductive network in the composites. Composites containing CNTs are known to have low percolation thresholds due to the high aspect ratio of the nanotubes.18 Most studies have found that CNT composites have percolation thresholds as low as 0.02 vol%, which is lower than those of other commercial carbon filler composites, such as carbon black (CB) and carbon nano fiber. Biercuk et al.19 observed that the CNT tends to form conductive paths at low filler loading, while carbon fibers require high filler loadings to form conductive paths. Dang et al.20 and Jiang et al.12 studied the effect of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) with different aspect ratios in methylvinyl silicone rubber (VMQ). They found that high aspect ratios contributed to the efficiency of the conducting network. However, the convolution and aggregation of the low aspect ratio fillers, such as CB, reduce the formation of the conductive path in the polymer matrix. According to Francis et al.,21 the size packing of the particles has to be taken into account to determine their effect on conductivity. Typically, CB concentrations between 5% and 20% in the polymer matrix are needed to reach the percolation threshold.22

The thermal stability of silicone rubber filled with conductive nanofillers has attracted considerable attention.23–27 Zhang et al.,28 in their study on the stability and the kinetics of the degradation of silicone rubber filled with CB, observed that the crosslinking agent can prevent the siloxane chains of the silicone rubber from degrading at high temperatures. They reported that the addition of the conductive fillers influenced the degradation of the siloxane chains. Different particle sizes have different effects on thermal degradation.29 Nanofillers were found to have high compactness that improved the thermal stability, as compared to micro-size fillers. In addition, only low levels of MWCNTs result in significantly increased thermal stability and improved electrical and thermal conductivity.30

Therefore, conductive carbon fillers can be added to the polymer matrix to improve the thermal and electrical properties of the composites. The thermal stability of the carbon nanofillers silicone rubber nanocomposites were investigated using thermogravimetry analysis (TGA). The electrical conductivity was measured using an Ultra High Resistance meter.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) type HIPEC Q1-4939, consisting of two parts, was obtained from Dow Corning, Michigan (USA) and used as the matrix. MWCNTs were purchased from Shenzhen Nanotech Port Co., Ltd. (China) with a purity >95%. The nanotubes were short-type tubes with lengths of 1–2 µm and external diameters of <10 nm. The density of the MWCNT measured by a gas pycnometer (Micromeritices, Accupyc 1330) was 1.44g/cm3. CB was purchased from Qingdao Cabot Import & Export Co. Ltd. The CB diameter was 40–80 nm. Toluene (100% CAS number 108-88-3) was obtained from JT Baker and used as the dispersing medium for the fillers.

sec.title: Preparation procedure
sec.p: The as-received multi-walled were added to toluene. The suspension was sonicated for 20 minutes. The effects of several volume fractions were studied. The fillers were then added to PDMS by stirring vigorously using a mechanical stirrer at 70°C to remove the toluene. Then, curing agent was added with continuous stirring. This solution was placed under vacuum to remove the trapped air. After degassing, the solution was cast on to a mold and pressed to the desired thickness. Molded samples were then cured in an oven at 150°C for one and a half hours. The final nanocomposite product appeared completely black. A similar procedure was used for CB nanocomposites.

sec.title: Sample characterization
sec.p: Micrographs of the cross sections of the fractured nanocomposites surfaces were obtained using a Zeiss Supra 35VP scanning electron microscope. Morphological analyses of the images were performed to determine the shape and dimensions of the particle inclusions. The fractured nanocomposite surfaces were observed to study the filler distribution, which may affect the conductivity and stability of the silicone rubber. A JEM-2100F (200 kV) transmission electron microscope was used to observe the tube dispersion in the silicone rubber.

The electrical resistivity of the carbon nanofiller/silicone rubber nanocomposites was measured using an Advantest R8340 Ultra High Resistance Meter. Samples of 2.5 cm × 2.5 cm × 0.1 cm were cut. The power used to study the resistivity was 500 W. The electrical resistance was calculated according to Equation (1): (1) where ρ is the static resistivity (Ωm), R is the electrical resistance (Ω), A is the cross-sectional area of the sample and ℓ is the thickness of the sample. The electrical conductivity is the reciprocal of the electrical resistivity.

The thermal stability and the thermal degradation behavior upon heating were studied using a TGA Perkin Elmer 6. Thermal analysis was conducted from 30 to 800°C under a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°C/min.

sec.title: Effect of different carbon nanofillers on the electrical conductivity of the composites
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows scanning electron micrographs of the fractured surface of MWCNT/PDMS and CB/PDMS nanocomposites with filler loadings of 0.5 and 2.0 vol%. The MWCNT was dispersed in the silicone rubber matrix, as shown in Figures 1(a) and (b). The MWCNT formed a conductive network that reduced the resistivity of the silicone rubber. The formation of a conductive network in 2.0 vol% for MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposites is supported by the transmission electron micrograph in Figure 2, showing tube–tube interaction between MWCNT inclusions. The darker region in the round circles indicates the presence of bundles or agglomerates of the MWCNT, while the lighter region in the square indicates the MWCNT scattered on the polymer matrix and less aggregate. In this region, the tubes, shown in light-gray color, are randomly orientated in the silicone rubber. Most of the tubes connected with each other to form a conductive network. Figure 1.
Cross-section of scanning electron micrograph of fractured multi-walled carbon nanotube/polydimethylsiloxane (MWCNT/PDMS) and carbon black (CB)/PDMS nanocomposites: (a) MWCNT/PDMS at 0.5 vol%; (b) MWCNT/PDMS at 2.0 vol%;(c) CB/PDMS at 0.5 vol%; and (d) CB/PDMS at 2.0 vol%. Figure 2.
Transmission electron micrograph showing the orientation of 2.0 vol% of multi-walled carbon nanotube in silicone rubber.

Figures 1(c) and 1(d) illustrate 0.5 and 2.0 vol% CB/PDMS nanocomposites. The arrow in Figure 1(c) indicates that CB particles are separated from each other. This fact is one of the reasons that the electrical resistivity did not decrease. However, at increased volume fractions, the CB particles tend to pack together and form large agglomerates. The CB agglomerates do not contact each other, and a conducting network is not formed. Therefore, high amounts of CB particles are required to produce a neighboring conductive particles effect. As reported by Wan et al.,31 nearly 40 wt % of CB was needed to create the conductive paths that reduced the resistivity of the CB nanocomposite.

Figure 3 shows electrical conductivity as a function of filler concentration for PDMS filled with MWCNT and CB fillers. There was a drastic increase in conductivity upon reaching the percolation threshold for MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposites. The conductivity increased from –10.29 to –2.62 log σ (S/cm). The percolation threshold where there is a sharp onset in conductivity was achieved at 1 vol% of MWCNTs in PDMS. On the contrary, CB/PDMS nanocomposites did not attain the percolation threshold. This is because there is no significance difference as CB filler was added ranging from 0.5 to 2.0 vol% in the PDMS. Results showed that, at 0.5 vol% of CB/PDMS nanocomposite, the conductivity value is –10.03 log σ (S/cm). After adding the CB filler up to 2.0 vol% in PDMS, the conductivity value was –9.88 log σ (S/cm). Figure 3.
Electrical conductivity of multi-walled carbon nanotube/polydimethylsiloxane (MWCNT/PDMS) and carbon black (CB)/PDMS nanocomposites with filler loadings from 0.5 to 2.0 vol%.

The large increment of conductivity value for MWCNT/PDMS compared to the CB/PDMS nanocomposites might be due to the different filler dimension. The MWCNT has a high surface area that consists of the l/d (length to diameter) ratio. Thus, the low-volume fraction of MWCNTs was enough for the tube–tube interaction in the composites to reach the percolation threshold and create a conductive path. The creation of a MWCNT conductive path allows the electrons to flow through the composites.32 The MWCNT consist of concentric multi-walled of tubes with the ends capped. As a result of this configuration, only the outer layer contributes to the electron transport that gives the composite its electrical properties.33 Vast et al.34 measured the conductivity of MWCNT/silicone elastomer nanocomposites and observed the rise in conductivity starting from 0.5 wt% and reached the plateau around 2 wt% with a conductivity value of ~2 log σ (S/cm). In our investigation, the conductivity plateau was reached at approximately 2 vol% of MWCNT loading with a conductivity value of –2.62 log σ (S/cm). Noted, it is difficult to compare the conductivity value between our work and others due to the different fraction units and dimension and type of CNT used. Only a relative comparison can be done.

A higher loading of CB fillers is needed to reach the percolation threshold as compared to MWCNTs. Francis et al.21 reported that changing the filler from CB to CNT in PVAc (polyvinyl acetate) decreased the percolation threshold from 2.5 to 0.02 vol%. About 0.02 vol% of CNT resulted in an electrical conductivity of –3.5 log σ (S/cm), while almost 2.5vol% of CB was needed to achieve a similar electrical conductivity. This suggested approximately about 125 times CB is needed in order to create a conductive path and obtain a similar conductivity value to CNT composites. Another factor impeding the formation of conductive channels in CB/PDMS nanocomposites is the agglomeration of the CB particles, as shown in Figure 1(d). Therefore, fewer interactions occurred between the CB fillers in the PDMS matrix. This could explain the low electrical conductivity of CB nanocomposites at filler concentrations ranging from 0.5 to 2.0 vol%.

The schematic drawing in Figure 4 explains the electrical behavior of the nanocomposite in terms of the orientation of the conductive carbon fillers used in the silicone rubber matrix. In the MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposites at low filler loadings, the conductive filler was distributed randomly with various orientations (Figure 4(a)). However, due to the effective l/d, the tube–tube interaction can occur when the distance between the tubes is very close. The conductive tube network creates the electrical conducting path that allows the electrons to tunnel through the tube channels by electron hopping between channels with direct tube–tube contact.35 As the tube loading increase up to 2.0 vol%, the MWCNT inclusions were in direct contact and reduced the electrical resistivity of the silicone rubber. As illustrated in Figure 4(b), the conductive CB particles did not result in electron tunneling due to the zero-dimensional structure of the fillers. In addition, at low CB/PDMS volume fractions, the particles were not in contact with each other. However, as the filler loading increased for CB/PDMS nanocomposites, the filler agglomerated and formed clusters of CB aggregates in certain regions of the nanocomposite. The filler clusters were not in contact with each other and the electron tunneling effect could not take place. Hence, the resistivity of the CB/PDMS nanocomposite was not reduced. Therefore, a higher volume of CB particles compared to MWCNTs is required for the conductive fillers to have direct contact with each other and create a conducting network. Figure 4.
Schematic of the percolation threshold of carbon nanofiller composites with filler loadings of 0.5 and 2.0 vol%: (a) multi-walled carbon nanotube/polydimethylsiloxane (MWCNT/PDMS) and (b) carbon black (CB)/PDMS.

sec.title: Thermal degradation of the carbon nanofiller composites
sec.p:
Polymer degradation may occur if the materials are exposed to relatively high temperatures for a long time. Therefore, it is crucial to understand the degradation behavior and the thermal stability of the composites under accelerated testing at elevated temperatures. The addition of filler to the silicone rubber restricted the mobility of the siloxane chains and hindered the molecular rearrangement of the PDMS chain.36 The TGA results for the nanocomposites are shown in Figure 5. The initial degradation temperature of PDMS was 258°C. Filling the PDMS with carbon nanofiller increased the initial burning temperature, as reported in Table 1. The weight loss during the initial stage of burning was attributed to the presence of moisture on the sample surface and to the volatile substances contained in the resin.37 As expected, the residual weight of the filled composites was higher than neat silicone rubber. The residue left after degradation of silicone rubber at 800°C consisted of traces of silica. At 620°C, the weight loss of silicone rubber is due to the polymerization of the siloxane chain.32 The combination of the silica and the remaining particle inclusions increases the residual weight of the nanocomposites. Figure 5.
Thermogravimetry analysis curves for multi-walled carbon nanotube/polydimethylsiloxane (MWCNT/PDMS) and carbon black (CB)/PDMS nanocomposites. Table 1.
Thermogravimetry analysis on multi-walled carbon nanotube/polydimethylsiloxane (MWCNT/PDMS) and carbon black (CB)/PDMS nanocomposites
Nanocomposites Loading (vol%) T10% (°C) Tonset (°C) Tmax (°C) Res (wt%)
PDMS – 473 472 513 29.45
MWCNT/PDMS 0.5 493 528 640 30.72
2.0 496 535 632 35.33
CB/PDMS 0.5 480 492 602 31.08
2.0 486 512 587 40.68

As listed in Table 1, the temperatures at 10% weight loss for 0.5 and 2.0 vol% MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposites were 493°C and 496°C, respectively, while the temperatures at 10% weight loss for the 0.5 and 2.0 vol% CB/PDMS nanocomposites were 480°C and 486°C, respectively. The synergistic effect of the tube–tube structure raises the onset temperature of the MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposite and shifted to a higher value as the filler loading increase to 2.0 vol% of the MWCNT nanocomposite. The high thermal conductivity of the MWCNT nanocomposite also resulted in a greater flow of heat throughout the sample. The MWCNT aggregates function as a barrier, preventing the diffusion of the degradation products from the bulky polymer into the gas phase.33 In addition, the entrapment of the polymer inside the tubes delayed the thermal degradation process,38 reducing the mobility of the silicone rubber around the nanotubes and improving the thermal stability of the MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposite. On the other hand, CB/PDMS nanocomposites showed a lower onset temperature, as the CB/PDMS nanocomposite was less thermally stable. Large discrepancies of the thermal stability between MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposites and CB/PDMS nanocomposites was attribute to the different dimensions and aspect ratios of the fillers. Aspect ratio plays an important role in determining the thermal stability and conductivity of the nanocomposites. A filler with a high aspect ratio can form bridges among the neighboring fillers and form a conductive network. Thus, the conductive network facilitates the electron and phonon transfer, which leads to high thermal stability and conductivity of the nanocomposites.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Carbon nanofillers have unique properties with exceptional electrical and thermal properties, making them excellent candidates for many applications, including electronic packaging. The MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposites reached the percolation threshold at 1 vol% of nanotube concentration, while CB/PDMS nanocomposites did not reach percolation threshold at a similar volume fraction. Thus, high filler concentrations are needed to form a percolating network in CB nanocomposites. The thermal stability for MWCNT/PDMS nanocomposites was higher than CB/PDMS nanocomposites, due to the difference in filler dimension and high aspect ratio of MWCNTs. The formation of conductive MWCNT tube pathways after nanotubes were added from 0.5 to 2.0 vol% tends to improve the conductivity and thermal stability of the nanocomposites as well.

In summary, MWCNTs have the potential of being reinforcing fillers. For future work, surface treatment of MWCNTs should be investigated to improve the surface interaction between MWCNTs and the silicone rubber matrix.
